docs.lead_paragraph: The first time Jolene Rudell fainted, she assumed that the stress of being in medical school had gotten to her. Then, two weeks later, she lost consciousness again. Blood tests showed Ms. Rudell's red blood cell count and iron level were dangerously low. But she is a hearty eater (and a carnivore), and her physician pointed to another possible culprit: a popular drug used by millions of Americans like Ms. Rudell to prevent gastroesophageal acid reflux, or severe heartburn.

headline.main: The Consumer: Combating Acid Reflux May Bring Host of Ills

docs.abstract: Many patients depend on proton pump inhibitors to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease, but their side effects can include nutritional deficits and vulnerability to infections; doctors maintain that in many individual cases the drug's benefits outweigh the dangers. (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The physicians who do the majority of the work at the Jackson Women’s Health Organization do not currently meet a new requirement that goes into effect on July 1.

headline.main: Mississippi’s Only Abortion Clinic at Risk as Law Nears
headline.print_headline: Mississippi’s Only Abortion Clinic Is at Risk as New Law Draws Near

docs.abstract: Jackson Women's Health Organization, Mississippi's only abortion clinic, faces an uncertain future due to a new law that will go into effect in July that requires all physicians associated with the clinic to have admitting privileges at local hospitals; it is widely known that none of the physicians who work at the clinic have such privileges, and three of the four doctors do not even live in the state.
docs.snippet: The physicians who do the majority of the work at the Jackson Women’s Health Organization do not currently meet a new requirement that goes into effect on July 1.
